+Jeff Nau
We average about one mass killing every two weeks. Out of about 240 
massacres, 173 were shootings, 60 were stabbing/blunt 
force/strangulation/fire/other, and 9 were a combination of shooting and 
some other form of lethal force. In England where guns are pretty much 
banned, knives, hammers and other lethal weapons are used more frequently 
now. The murder rate has went down in UK and the USA.

I couldn't get a specific number, but the murders in UK that used knives or 
blunt force are far and away more prevalent than murders that used guns. 
Knives and blunt weapons have replaced guns. The UK has been increasing 
restrictions on knives, bats, hammers, etc. but it has had little impact on 
murders or violent crime.

The UK murder rates are statistically far lower than the USA, but the UK 
uses only murders that have a legal conviction. For example, Dr Harold 
Shipman was convicted of 172 murders that occurred over a two decade 
period. Everyone knew those victims were murdered, but the murders did not 
count UNTIL Shipman was convicted THEN all 172 murders were lumped into one 
year. The USA counts murders whether or not the murderer is found; 
therefore, the USA murder rates will look much higher than the UK. I don't 
know what the comparable murder rate truly is in the UK, but it is much, 
much higher than reported.

When comparing statistics between two countries, it is impossible to get 
accurate reports. Different definitions of crime and differing 
methodologies cannot produce accurate comparisons.

In the U.S. the place with by far the most restrictive gun control is the 
District of Columbia. It also has the highest gun murder rate of any place 
in the USA. The gun ban in D.C. has been lifted; consequently, the murder 
rate is at its lowest point since in 1976 when the gun ban was first 
enacted. However, it still remains as the place with the highest gun murder 
rate and still has the most restrictive gun laws.

Let me do a more apples to apples comparison with States within the USA. 
According to the Brady Campaign, the state with the most restrictive gun 
control laws is California, yet that state has the highest gun murder rate 
(3.25 gun murders per 100,000 people). According to the Brady Campaign, the 
state with the least restrictive gun control laws is Utah, yet that state 
has the lowest gun murder rate (.97 gun murders per 100,000 people).

That was a long ass response, but wanted to give you some numbers to think 
about. If you can dispute those or put those in a perspective that would 
support more gun control, then I would like to hear that. As far as I 
understand, gun control doesn't work and more guns equals fewer mass 
murders and other violent crimes.
